    Association AnalysisÂ¶

    ==Itemset==ã€‚A collection of one or more items. k-itemset: An itemset that contains k items. ==Support count Ïƒ==ã€‚ Frequency of occurrence of an itemset. ==Support s==ã€‚Fraction of transactions that contain an itemset. ==Frequent itemset==ã€‚An itemset whose support is greater than or equal to a â€œminsupâ€ threshold. ==Confidence c==ã€‚Measures how often items in Y appear in records that contain X.

    !!! p â€œRules originating from the same itemset have identical support but can have different confidence.â€

    æ‰€ä»¥å¯ä»¥åˆ†å¼€ç®—ã€‚å…ˆç®— support åç®— confidenceã€‚

    ==Association Rule==ã€‚An implication expression of form X to Y where X and Y are itemsets. ==Association Rule Mining Task==ã€‚Given a set of transactions T, the goal of association rule mining is to find all rules having

    • support â‰¥ minsup threshold;

    • confidence â‰¥ minconf threshold.

    > > ![](./pics/AssociaA_2.png){width=60%} > > > > Compute the support and confidence of the association rule {Milk, Diaper} â†’ {Beer}. > > N = 5 = the total number of transactions > Ïƒ({Milk, Bread, Diaper}) = 2. > Support s({Milk, Bread, Diaper}) = $frac{sigma}{N}=frac{2}{5}$ > Association Rule = {Milk, Diaper} -> {Beer} > Confidence c=$cfrac{sigma(MDB)}{sigma(MD)}=frac{2}{3}$

    approachÂ¶

    • Frequent Itemset Generation: Generate all itemsets whose <u>support â‰¥ minsup</u>.

    Given $d$ items, there are $2^d âˆ’ 1$ possible candidate itemsets.

    • Rule Generation: Generate <u>high confidence</u> rules from each frequent itemset.

    Brute-force approach æš´åŠ›è§£ã€‚åˆ—å‡ºå¹¶æ±‚å‡ºå…¨éƒ¨ã€‚Computationally prohibitive! Each frequent itemset of size $n$ leads to $2^nâˆ’2$ association rules X â†’ Y. æ¯ä¸ªiteméƒ½æœ‰æˆä¸ºXå’ŒYä¸¤ç§å¯èƒ½ï¼Œç„¶åå‡æ‰Xæˆ–Yä¸ºç©ºçš„ä¸¤ç§æƒ…å†µã€‚

    Apriori principle

    • {A} Non-frequenct, $implies$ {AB}, {AC} æ›´ä¸¥è‹›çš„è¦æ±‚ä¸€å®šæ˜¯ Non-frequent.ã€itemsetã€‘ã€supportã€‘

    Frequent Pattern (FP)-growth algorithm Using the data structure FP-tree to extract frequent itemsets directly. An FP-tree is a compressed representation of the input. å°†ç›¸åŒç‚¹è¿æ¥ï¼Œé€†å‘æ‰¾å¯»

    Association Rule å…³è”è§„åˆ™Â¶

    An association rule is an implication of the formÂ ğ´ â‡’ ğµ, whereÂ ğ´Â is the Antecedent,Â ğµÂ is the Consequent.

    Support-Confidence FrameworkÂ¶

    ğŸ’¡ support(itemset) æ”¯æŒåº¦ ABæœ‰å…³ confidence(associate rule)ç½®ä¿¡åº¦ Aæ¨B è€Œä¸æ˜¯Bæ¨A

    min_sup : a minimum support threshold $implies$ whether a frequent itemset $L_k$

    How to developÂ¶

    1. è®¾å®šä¸€ä¸ªminimum support thresholdï¼Œæ‰¾åˆ° frequent itemset $L_k$

    2. GenerateÂ StrongÂ Association Rules from the Frequent Itemsets

    • Example

      support_count({I1,I2})$=#T(I1cup I2)=4$

      (T100ï¼ŒT200ï¼ŒT400ï¼ŒT800

      support({I1,I2})=$frac{text{support_count}({ I1,I2})}{T}=frac{4}{9}$
